title: Quick Favor - alternative for MS Trebuchet
content: Looking for the US ARMY font for PT Shirts. I think its Trebuchet Bold ... but alas I have Win 2K no Trebuchet ... any look a likes I may use?
author: negood

comments.content:
If you look at [this page](http://web.archive.org/web/20130921050339/http:/bowfinprintworks.com/SansIDPage09.html) in the Sans Serif Font ID Guide, you can see other styles with similar shape characteristics to Trebuchet: Agenda (Font Bureau), Faceplate Sans (Psy/Ops), Mahsuri Sans (Agfa), Today Sans (Spiece), Parisine Bold(Agfa), and Projekt (Linotype). Of course details will not match in each font, like the serif on the 'i', or the curved 'l', or the open lower bowl on the 'g'.   
   
However, finding an equivalent seems like an odd exercise for such a ubiquitous font. Doesn't Microsoft give it away?

The MS core fonts, including Trebuchet, are available from   
 [Sourceforge](http://web.archive.org/web/20130921050339/http:/sourceforge.net/project/showfiles.php?group_id=34153&release_id=105355).
I dont know about most ... but I for one appreciate all of the help from this forum. It is a valuable tool for the newbie. So thanks to all.
Wayne, I think [it's safe to say that we all share your opinion](http://web.archive.org/web/20130921050339/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/22666.html?1072921486)!

Sorry for the delay, Yves.   
   
Well, MS wants people to pay, not for the fonts per se, but for the   
program(s) that bundle the fonts. That was the main point put to   
me by an upper level MS Typography rep who actually replied to   
my e-mailed inquiry (boy, was I surprised).   
   
Outside opinion, based partly on the timing, was that Linux users   
were being pointed to those fonts by many Linux resource sites   
and were grabbing them in very large numbers.   
   
Certainly it's MS' right to do with the fonts what they choose, but   
increasingly they have been choosing to slap their customers   
upside the head. The user of a properly purchased MS application   
who has a font that has become corrupted cannot simply get a   
replacement off the installation CD. The fonts don't exist as indi-   
vidual files.   
   
Personally, I feel that, after making sure that Arial, TNR and, to a   
lesser extent, Verdana are specified in millions of HTML pages   
around the world, MS ought to make these fonts available to all.   
   
Of course, as Justin showed, the fonts are available elsewhere.
Microsoft DOES give them out, that office updateI linked to just installs a bunch of Standard fonts, including Trebuchet.

Sort of, Aleph. That download was not provided for MS' users   
to replace missing/corrupted fonts. It's there so that users can   
obtain updated "euro enabled" versions of the fonts. Plainly   
missing are the regular Arial variants, Georgia and Times New   
Roman.   
   
It also likely does nothing for the many folks without MS apps   
who visit web pages coded for Arial, TNR, Verdana, etc. I don't   
know for sure about this download, but most MS installations   
check for a valid MS application

MS Trebuchet is a very distinct face - regardless   
if you like it or not - so it's pretty difficult to find an   
acceptable match. Do you want to match principally   
the uppercase or lowercase?
